Actinobacillus Pleuropneumonia.description: A bacterial disease causing pleuropneumonia in pigs, leading to severe respiratory distress and lung lesions.
Actinobacillus Pleuropneumonia.treatment: Treatment includes antibiotics and improved herd management; vaccination and biosecurity measures help prevent outbreaks.

Actinobacillus Suis.description: A bacterial infection in pigs that can cause septicemia, pneumonia, and sudden death, especially in young pigs.
Actinobacillus Suis.treatment: Antibiotic therapy is recommended; good hygiene and management practices reduce risk.

African Swine Fever.description: A highly contagious viral disease of pigs characterized by fever, internal bleeding, and high mortality.
African Swine Fever.treatment: There is no specific treatment; control relies on strict biosecurity, culling, and movement restrictions.

Allergic Rhinitis.description: An inflammatory condition of the nasal mucosa in animals, often caused by allergens such as dust or pollen.
Allergic Rhinitis.treatment: Management includes reducing exposure to allergens and administering antihistamines or corticosteroids.

Arthritis.description: Inflammation of the joints, which can be caused by infection, injury, or degenerative conditions in animals.
Arthritis.treatment: Treatment depends on the cause and may include antibiotics, anti-inflammatory drugs, and supportive care.

Blue Tongue.description: A viral disease affecting ruminants, especially sheep, causing fever, swelling, and cyanosis of the tongue.
Blue Tongue.treatment: No specific treatment; supportive care and vector control are important. Vaccination is available in some regions.

Blue Tongue Disease.description: Another term for Bluetongue, a viral disease of ruminants transmitted by biting midges.
Blue Tongue Disease.treatment: Supportive care and vector control; vaccination can help prevent outbreaks.

Blue Tongue Virus.description: The virus responsible for Bluetongue disease in ruminants, primarily affecting sheep and cattle.
Blue Tongue Virus.treatment: No direct treatment; prevention relies on vaccination and controlling insect vectors.

Bluetongue.description: A non-contagious, insect-borne viral disease of ruminants, especially sheep, causing fever and swelling of the mouth and tongue.
Bluetongue.treatment: Supportive care and vector control; vaccination is used in endemic areas.

Bluetongue Virus.description: The causative agent of Bluetongue disease in ruminants, especially sheep.
Bluetongue Virus.treatment: Management includes vaccination and reducing exposure to insect vectors.

Bordetella Infection.description: A bacterial infection in animals, often causing respiratory disease such as atrophic rhinitis in pigs and kennel cough in dogs.
Bordetella Infection.treatment: Treatment includes antibiotics and supportive care; vaccination and good hygiene help prevent infection.

Bovine Coccidiosis.description: A parasitic disease in cattle caused by Eimeria species, leading to diarrhea and weight loss, especially in young animals.
Bovine Coccidiosis.treatment: Anticoccidial drugs and improved sanitation are used for treatment and prevention.

Bovine Influenza.description: A viral respiratory disease in cattle, causing fever, coughing, and nasal discharge.
Bovine Influenza.treatment: Supportive care is provided; vaccination and biosecurity measures help prevent outbreaks.

Bovine Johne's Disease.description: A chronic bacterial infection in cattle caused by Mycobacterium avium subspecies paratuberculosis, resulting in diarrhea and weight loss.
Bovine Johne's Disease.treatment: There is no effective treatment; control relies on herd management and culling of infected animals.

Bovine Leukemia Virus.description: A retrovirus that infects cattle, causing enzootic bovine leukosis, which may lead to lymphosarcoma.
Bovine Leukemia Virus.treatment: No specific treatment; control is based on testing and removing infected animals from the herd.

Bovine Mastitis.description: An inflammation of the mammary gland in dairy cattle, usually caused by bacterial infection, leading to reduced milk production and quality.
Bovine Mastitis.treatment: Treatment includes intramammary antibiotics and improved milking hygiene; prevention focuses on sanitation and culling chronic cases.

Bovine Parainfluenza.description: A viral respiratory infection in cattle caused by parainfluenza virus type 3, resulting in coughing, nasal discharge, and fever.
Bovine Parainfluenza.treatment: Supportive care and vaccination are the main strategies for control and prevention.

Bovine Pneumonia.description: A respiratory disease in cattle characterized by inflammation of the lungs, often caused by bacteria or viruses.
Bovine Pneumonia.treatment: Treatment includes antibiotics, anti-inflammatories, and supportive care; prevention involves vaccination and good management.

Bovine Respiratory Disease.description: A complex of respiratory infections in cattle, often involving multiple pathogens and stress factors, leading to pneumonia and economic loss.
Bovine Respiratory Disease.treatment: Treatment includes antibiotics, anti-inflammatories, and supportive care; prevention relies on vaccination and minimizing stress.

Bovine Respiratory Disease Complex.description: A multifactorial respiratory illness in cattle involving viruses, bacteria, and environmental stressors.
Bovine Respiratory Disease Complex.treatment: Management includes antibiotics, supportive care, and vaccination programs.

Bovine Respiratory Syncytial Virus.description: A viral infection in cattle causing respiratory disease, especially in young calves, with symptoms like coughing and nasal discharge.
Bovine Respiratory Syncytial Virus.treatment: Supportive care and vaccination are used for treatment and prevention.

Bovine Tuberculosis.description: A chronic bacterial disease in cattle caused by Mycobacterium bovis, leading to the formation of tubercles in organs, especially the lungs.
Bovine Tuberculosis.treatment: There is no effective treatment; control relies on testing, culling, and movement restrictions.

Bovine Viral Diarrhea.description: A contagious viral disease in cattle caused by Bovine Viral Diarrhea Virus (BVDV), resulting in diarrhea, immunosuppression, and reproductive losses.
Bovine Viral Diarrhea.treatment: Supportive care and vaccination are used for control and prevention.

Canine Cough.description: Also known as kennel cough, a highly contagious respiratory disease in dogs caused by various viruses and bacteria, including Bordetella bronchiseptica.
Canine Cough.treatment: Treatment includes cough suppressants, antibiotics if bacterial infection is present, and vaccination for prevention.

Canine Distemper.description: A serious viral disease in dogs caused by canine distemper virus, affecting the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and nervous systems.
Canine Distemper.treatment: No specific treatment; supportive care and vaccination are essential for prevention.

Canine Flu.description: A contagious respiratory disease in dogs caused by canine influenza virus, leading to coughing, fever, and nasal discharge.
Canine Flu.treatment: Supportive care is provided; vaccination can help prevent infection.

Canine Heartworm Disease.description: A parasitic disease in dogs caused by Dirofilaria immitis, leading to heart and lung damage.
Canine Heartworm Disease.treatment: Treatment involves specific antiparasitic medications; prevention is achieved with regular heartworm preventives.

Canine Hepatitis.description: A viral infection in dogs caused by canine adenovirus type 1, affecting the liver and other organs.
Canine Hepatitis.treatment: Supportive care is provided; vaccination is effective for prevention.

Canine Infectious Hepatitis.description: A contagious viral disease in dogs caused by canine adenovirus type 1, resulting in liver inflammation and systemic illness.
Canine Infectious Hepatitis.treatment: Supportive care and vaccination are key for management and prevention.

Canine Influenza.description: A contagious respiratory disease in dogs caused by canine influenza virus, leading to coughing, fever, and nasal discharge.
Canine Influenza.treatment: Supportive care is provided; vaccination can help prevent infection.

Canine Leptospirosis.description: A bacterial disease in dogs caused by Leptospira species, affecting the kidneys and liver.
Canine Leptospirosis.treatment: Antibiotic therapy and supportive care are used; vaccination and avoiding contaminated water help prevent infection.

Canine Parvovirus.description: A highly contagious viral disease in dogs, especially puppies, causing severe vomiting and diarrhea.
Canine Parvovirus.treatment: Supportive care is critical; vaccination is the best prevention.

Caprine Arthritis.description: A chronic joint disease in goats, often caused by Caprine Arthritis Encephalitis Virus (CAEV).
Caprine Arthritis.treatment: No cure; management includes supportive care and culling affected animals.

Caprine Arthritis Encephalitis.description: A viral disease in goats caused by CAEV, leading to arthritis, encephalitis, and mastitis.
Caprine Arthritis Encephalitis.treatment: No specific treatment; control relies on herd management and culling infected animals.

Caprine Arthritis Encephalitis Virus.description: The virus responsible for Caprine Arthritis Encephalitis in goats, causing chronic joint and neurological disease.
Caprine Arthritis Encephalitis Virus.treatment: No cure; prevention is based on testing and removing infected animals.

Caprine Pleuropneumonia.description: A contagious bacterial disease in goats, causing severe pneumonia and pleuritis.
Caprine Pleuropneumonia.treatment: Antibiotic therapy and improved management practices are recommended.

Caprine Respiratory Disease.description: A group of respiratory illnesses in goats caused by various pathogens, leading to coughing and breathing difficulties.
Caprine Respiratory Disease.treatment: Treatment depends on the cause and may include antibiotics and supportive care; good management helps prevent outbreaks.

Caprine Viral Arthritis.description: A viral disease in goats, similar to Caprine Arthritis Encephalitis, causing chronic joint inflammation.
Caprine Viral Arthritis.treatment: No cure; management includes supportive care and culling affected animals.

Caseous Lymphadenitis.description: A chronic bacterial infection in sheep and goats caused by Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis, leading to abscesses in lymph nodes.
Caseous Lymphadenitis.treatment: Abscess drainage and antibiotics may help; control relies on culling and good hygiene.

Chlamydia in Sheep.description: A bacterial infection in sheep caused by Chlamydia species, often resulting in abortion or conjunctivitis.
Chlamydia in Sheep.treatment: Antibiotic therapy and improved management practices are recommended.

Chronic Bronchitis.description: A long-term inflammation of the bronchi in animals, leading to persistent cough and respiratory distress.
Chronic Bronchitis.treatment: Management includes reducing exposure to irritants and providing supportive care; bronchodilators may be used.

Coccidiosis.description: A parasitic disease caused by Eimeria species, affecting the intestines of many animals and leading to diarrhea and weight loss.
Coccidiosis.treatment: Anticoccidial drugs and improved sanitation are used for treatment and prevention.

Conjunctivitis.description: Inflammation of the conjunctiva in animals, often caused by infection, irritants, or allergens.
Conjunctivitis.treatment: Treatment depends on the cause and may include antibiotics, anti-inflammatories, and removing irritants.

Contagious Abortion.description: A term for infectious causes of abortion in livestock, such as Brucella or Chlamydia species.
Contagious Abortion.treatment: Treatment and prevention depend on the specific pathogen and may include antibiotics, vaccination, and improved biosecurity.

Contagious Ecthyma.description: Also known as Orf, a viral skin disease in sheep and goats causing pustular lesions around the mouth and nose.
Contagious Ecthyma.treatment: Lesions usually heal without treatment; supportive care and good hygiene are recommended.

Cryptosporidiosis.description: A parasitic disease caused by Cryptosporidium species, leading to diarrhea in young animals.
Cryptosporidiosis.treatment: Supportive care is the main treatment; improved sanitation helps prevent outbreaks.

Degenerative Joint Disease.description: A chronic condition in animals characterized by the breakdown of joint cartilage, leading to pain and reduced mobility.
Degenerative Joint Disease.treatment: Management includes weight control, anti-inflammatory drugs, and joint supplements; surgery may be needed in severe cases.

Distemper.description: A highly contagious viral disease affecting dogs and some wildlife, causing respiratory, gastrointestinal, and neurological symptoms.
Distemper.treatment: No specific treatment; supportive care and vaccination are essential for prevention.

Enteritis.description: Inflammation of the intestines in animals, often caused by infection, leading to diarrhea and dehydration.
Enteritis.treatment: Treatment includes fluid therapy, dietary management, and addressing the underlying cause.

Equine Arthritis.description: A condition in horses characterized by joint inflammation, pain, and reduced mobility, often due to injury or aging.
Equine Arthritis.treatment: Management includes rest, anti-inflammatory drugs, joint supplements, and sometimes surgery.

Equine Cushing's Disease.description: A hormonal disorder in horses caused by dysfunction of the pituitary gland, leading to abnormal hair growth and laminitis.
Equine Cushing's Disease.treatment: Medical management with drugs like pergolide and dietary changes are recommended.

Equine Encephalitis.description: A general term for inflammation of the brain in horses, often caused by viruses like Eastern, Western, or Venezuelan Equine Encephalitis viruses.
Equine Encephalitis.treatment: Supportive care, anti-inflammatory drugs, and fluid therapy. Specific antiviral treatments are usually unavailable.

Equine Encephalomyelitis.description: A group of mosquito-borne viral diseases (Eastern, Western, Venezuelan) that cause inflammation of the brain and spinal cord in horses.
Equine Encephalomyelitis.treatment: Primarily supportive care, including anti-inflammatory medications, fluids, and managing neurological symptoms. Vaccination is key for prevention.

Equine Herpesvirus.description: A family of viruses (EHV-1, EHV-4 are common) that can cause respiratory disease, abortion, and neurological issues in horses.
Equine Herpesvirus.treatment: Supportive care, anti-inflammatory drugs, and antivirals in some cases. Vaccination helps reduce severity and spread.

Equine Infectious Anemia.description: A viral disease of horses, ponies, and donkeys transmitted by blood-feeding insects, causing fever, anemia, and edema.
Equine Infectious Anemia.treatment: No vaccine or cure; infected animals are lifelong carriers and typically require quarantine or euthanasia to prevent spread.

Equine Influenza.description: A highly contagious viral respiratory disease in horses, causing fever, coughing, and nasal discharge.
Equine Influenza.treatment: Rest, supportive care, and anti-inflammatory medications. Vaccination is effective for prevention.

Equine Influenza Virus.description: The specific virus (Orthomyxoviridae family) responsible for equine influenza.
Equine Influenza Virus.treatment: Supportive care, rest, and anti-inflammatories. Prevention via vaccination is crucial.

Equine Laminitis.description: A painful inflammatory condition of the laminae within the hoof, leading to lameness and potential rotation of the coffin bone.
Equine Laminitis.treatment: Pain management, corrective farriery, dietary changes, and addressing the underlying cause (e.g., metabolic issues, concussion).

Equine Leptospirosis.description: Bacterial disease in horses, primarily affecting the kidneys and eyes (equine recurrent uveitis), spread via contaminated water/urine.
Equine Leptospirosis.treatment: Antibiotics (e.g., tetracyclines) and anti-inflammatory drugs. May require long-term management for chronic eye issues.

Equine Lyme Disease.description: Bacterial infection caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted by ticks, leading to lameness, arthritis, and neurological signs.
Equine Lyme Disease.treatment: Prolonged courses of antibiotics (e.g., tetracyclines or penicillin).

Equine Metabolic Syndrome.description: An endocrine disorder characterized by insulin dysregulation, obesity, and an increased risk of laminitis.
Equine Metabolic Syndrome.treatment: Dietary management (low non-structural carbohydrates), exercise, and medications to improve insulin sensitivity.

Equine Osteoarthritis.description: Degenerative joint disease in horses, causing progressive cartilage loss, bone changes, and lameness.
Equine Osteoarthritis.treatment: Pain management (NSAIDs), joint injections (corticosteroids, hyaluronan), physical therapy, and joint supplements.

Equine Piroplasmosis.description: Tick-borne parasitic disease affecting red blood cells, causing fever, anemia, and jaundice.
Equine Piroplasmosis.treatment: Antiprotozoal drugs (e.g., imidocarb dipropionate). Testing and eradication programs are common in affected areas.

Equine Pneumonia.description: Inflammation of the lungs in horses, often caused by bacterial or viral infections, leading to coughing, fever, and labored breathing.
Equine Pneumonia.treatment: Antibiotics (for bacterial), anti-inflammatory drugs, bronchodilators, and supportive care.

Equine Protozoal Myeloencephalitis.description: Neurological disease caused by the protozoan Sarcocystis neurona, leading to ataxia, weakness, and muscle atrophy.
Equine Protozoal Myeloencephalitis.treatment: Antiprotozoal drugs (e.g., ponazuril, diclazuril) and supportive care.

Equine Rhinopneumonitis.description: A common name for diseases caused by Equine Herpesvirus types 1 (EHV-1) and 4 (EHV-4), affecting respiratory, reproductive, and neurological systems.
Equine Rhinopneumonitis.treatment: Supportive care, anti-inflammatory medications, and antivirals in some cases. Vaccination is preventative.

Equine Viral Arteritis.description: Contagious viral disease causing respiratory illness, abortion, and edema in horses; spread through respiratory secretions and semen.
Equine Viral Arteritis.treatment: Supportive care and isolation. Vaccination is available for breeding animals and those at risk.

Equine West Nile Virus.description: Mosquito-borne viral disease causing neurological signs like ataxia, muscle tremors, and weakness in horses.
Equine West Nile Virus.treatment: Supportive care, anti-inflammatory drugs, and fluid therapy. Vaccination is highly effective for prevention.

Feline Asthma.description: Chronic inflammatory condition of the airways in cats, causing coughing, wheezing, and difficulty breathing.
Feline Asthma.treatment: Corticosteroids (oral or inhaled) and bronchodilators to reduce inflammation and open airways.

Feline Calicivirus.description: A highly contagious viral infection in cats causing oral ulcers, respiratory signs, and sometimes lameness.
Feline Calicivirus.treatment: Supportive care, including fluid therapy, pain management, and nutritional support. Antibiotics for secondary bacterial infections.

Feline Chlamydia.description: Bacterial infection (Chlamydophila felis) in cats primarily causing conjunctivitis (eye inflammation).
Feline Chlamydia.treatment: Antibiotics, usually topical or oral tetracyclines.

Feline Chlamydiosis.description: Another name for Feline Chlamydia, a bacterial infection causing conjunctivitis and mild respiratory signs.

Feline Coronavirus.description: A common viral infection in cats, often causing mild gastrointestinal signs. Can mutate to Feline Infectious Peritonitis (FIP).
Feline Coronavirus.treatment: Supportive care for mild cases. No specific antiviral for common coronavirus; FIP treatment is emerging but complex.

Feline Herpesvirus.description: Also known as Feline Viral Rhinotracheitis (FVR), a common viral cause of upper respiratory infections in cats.
Feline Herpesvirus.treatment: Supportive care, including fluid therapy, nasal decongestants, and sometimes antiviral medications. Antibiotics for secondary bacterial infections.

Feline Immunodeficiency Virus.description: A retrovirus that weakens a cat's immune system, making them susceptible to secondary infections.
Feline Immunodeficiency Virus.treatment: No cure; management focuses on supportive care, preventing secondary infections, and maintaining overall health.

Feline Infectious Peritonitis.description: A fatal, progressive disease caused by a mutated feline coronavirus, leading to widespread inflammation and organ damage.
Feline Infectious Peritonitis.treatment: Historically fatal; new antiviral treatments are emerging but are not universally available or approved.

Feline Leukemia.description: A common term for Feline Leukemia Virus (FeLV) infection, a retrovirus that can cause various cancers, immune suppression, and anemia.
Feline Leukemia.treatment: No cure; management focuses on supportive care, treating secondary infections, and managing symptoms. Vaccination is available for prevention.

Feline Leukemia Virus.description: A retrovirus that significantly suppresses a cat's immune system, leading to various diseases including lymphoma and anemia.
Feline Leukemia Virus.treatment: No cure; supportive care, managing opportunistic infections, and addressing secondary conditions. Prevention through vaccination.

Feline Panleukopenia.description: A highly contagious and often fatal viral disease in cats, especially kittens, causing severe gastrointestinal, immune, and neurological issues.
Feline Panleukopenia.treatment: Intensive supportive care including IV fluids, anti-nausea medication, antibiotics for secondary infections, and nutritional support.

Feline Panleukopenia Virus.description: The parvovirus responsible for Feline Panleukopenia, leading to severe illness and high mortality rates in unvaccinated cats.
Feline Panleukopenia Virus.treatment: Aggressive supportive care is crucial. Prevention is through vaccination.

Feline Renal Disease.description: Chronic kidney disease in cats, a progressive and irreversible loss of kidney function.
Feline Renal Disease.treatment: Dietary management, fluid therapy, medications to control symptoms (e.g., phosphorus binders, blood pressure meds), and supportive care.

Feline Respiratory Disease Complex.description: A collective term for various viral and bacterial infections causing upper respiratory symptoms in cats, primarily Feline Herpesvirus and Calicivirus.
Feline Respiratory Disease Complex.treatment: Supportive care (fluids, nutritional support), antibiotics for bacterial components, and sometimes antivirals.

Feline Respiratory Infection.description: General term for infections affecting the respiratory system of cats, often causing sneezing, nasal discharge, and coughing.
Feline Respiratory Infection.treatment: Depends on the cause (viral/bacterial); supportive care, antibiotics (if bacterial), and anti-inflammatory drugs.

Feline Rhinotracheitis.description: A specific viral infection in cats caused by Feline Herpesvirus-1, leading to acute upper respiratory signs and conjunctivitis.
Feline Rhinotracheitis.treatment: Supportive care, fluid therapy, and sometimes antiviral medications. Antibiotics for secondary bacterial infections.

Feline Upper Respiratory Infection.description: A common ailment in cats, typically caused by Feline Herpesvirus and/or Calicivirus, resulting in sneezing, nasal discharge, and eye issues.
Feline Upper Respiratory Infection.treatment: Supportive care (hydration, nutrition), antibiotics for secondary bacterial infections, and symptomatic relief.

Feline Viral Rhinotracheitis.description: Another name for Feline Herpesvirus infection, a primary cause of upper respiratory disease in cats.
Feline Viral Rhinotracheitis.treatment: Supportive care, hydration, and sometimes antiviral drugs. Antibiotics are used if bacterial infections occur.

Foot and Mouth Disease.description: A highly contagious viral disease of cloven-hoofed animals, causing fever and vesicular lesions (blisters) in the mouth and on the feet.
Foot and Mouth Disease.treatment: No specific antiviral treatment; control involves culling affected and exposed animals, strict biosecurity, and vaccination in endemic areas.

Foot-and-Mouth Disease.description: Synonymous with Foot and Mouth Disease, a severe, highly contagious viral disease affecting cloven-hoofed livestock.
Foot-and-Mouth Disease.treatment: Control measures include quarantine, culling, movement restrictions, and vaccination in specific regions.

Footrot.description: A contagious bacterial infection of the hoof in sheep and goats, causing lameness and foul-smelling lesions.
Footrot.treatment: Foot trimming, topical treatments (e.g., zinc sulfate), footbaths, and antibiotics (injectable for severe cases).

Fungal Infection.description: Diseases caused by various types of fungi, affecting skin, respiratory system, or internal organs, depending on the species and location.
Fungal Infection.treatment: Antifungal medications (topical or systemic), duration varies based on type and severity of infection.

Gastroenteritis.description: Inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, causing vomiting and diarrhea, often due to infection, diet, or toxins.
Gastroenteritis.treatment: Supportive care, fluid therapy, anti-nausea medications, dietary management, and specific treatment for underlying cause if identified.

Gastrointestinal Infection.description: Infection of the digestive system by bacteria, viruses, or parasites, leading to symptoms like vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.
Gastrointestinal Infection.treatment: Varies by pathogen; includes antibiotics, antivirals, antiparasitics, fluid therapy, and supportive care.

Gastrointestinal Stasis.description: A reduction or complete halt of food movement through the digestive tract, common in rabbits, leading to anorexia and bloating.
Gastrointestinal Stasis.treatment: Aggressive fluid therapy, pain relief, prokinetics (motility drugs), and addressing underlying causes.

Giardiasis.description: Intestinal infection caused by the microscopic parasite Giardia, leading to diarrhea, especially in young animals.
Giardiasis.treatment: Antiparasitic medications (e.g., fenbendazole, metronidazole) and sanitation to prevent reinfection.

Goat Pox.description: A contagious viral disease of goats, causing skin lesions, fever, and sometimes respiratory signs.
Goat Pox.treatment: No specific antiviral; supportive care, managing secondary infections. Vaccination is used in endemic areas.

Heartworm Disease.description: A serious and potentially fatal parasitic disease transmitted by mosquitoes, where worms live in the heart, lungs, and blood vessels.
Heartworm Disease.treatment: Complex and lengthy, involving adulticide injections to kill worms, strict rest, and preventive medication. Prevention is key.

Hyperthyroidism.description: A common endocrine disorder in older cats, caused by overactive thyroid glands, leading to weight loss, increased appetite, and hyperactivity.
Hyperthyroidism.treatment: Medication (e.g., methimazole), radioactive iodine therapy, or surgical removal of the thyroid gland.

Inflammatory Bowel Disease.description: A chronic condition in animals where the gastrointestinal tract becomes inflamed due to an abnormal immune response.
Inflammatory Bowel Disease.treatment: Dietary changes, immunosuppressive medications (e.g., corticosteroids), and antibiotics for secondary bacterial overgrowth.

Intestinal Parasites.description: Worms (e.g., roundworms, hookworms, tapeworms) or protozoa (e.g., coccidia) living in the intestines, causing digestive upset, poor growth, or other symptoms.
Intestinal Parasites.treatment: Specific deworming medications (anthelmintics) or antiprotozoal drugs, and regular fecal exams for prevention.

Johne's Disease.description: A chronic, progressive intestinal disease in ruminants caused by Mycobacterium avium subspecies paratuberculosis, leading to weight loss and diarrhea.
Johne's Disease.treatment: No effective treatment; infected animals are usually culled to prevent spread. Prevention focuses on herd management and sanitation.

Kennel Cough.description: A highly contagious respiratory disease in dogs, typically caused by a combination of viruses and bacteria, resulting in a harsh, dry cough.
Kennel Cough.treatment: Rest, cough suppressants, and antibiotics for secondary bacterial infections. Vaccination is available for prevention.

Laminitis.description: Painful inflammatory condition of the laminae within the hoof, common in horses, leading to lameness.
Laminitis.treatment: Pain management, corrective farriery, dietary changes, and addressing the underlying cause.

Leptospirosis.description: Bacterial disease affecting various animals and humans, causing kidney and liver damage; spread via contaminated water/urine.
Leptospirosis.treatment: Antibiotics (e.g., doxycycline) and supportive care; vaccination is available for some species.

Lyme Disease.description: Tick-borne bacterial infection (Borrelia burgdorferi) affecting various animals, causing lameness, joint pain, and other systemic signs.
Lyme Disease.treatment: Prolonged courses of antibiotics (e.g., doxycycline); prevention through tick control and vaccination in endemic areas.

Maedi-Visna.description: A chronic, progressive viral disease of sheep (and goats) primarily causing respiratory (Maedi) and neurological (Visna) signs.
Maedi-Visna.treatment: No cure; management involves culling infected animals to prevent spread. Prevention focuses on herd management and testing.

Mastitis.description: Inflammation of the mammary gland, common in dairy animals, caused by bacterial infection, leading to decreased milk production and altered milk quality.
Mastitis.treatment: Antibiotics (intramammary or systemic), anti-inflammatory drugs, and supportive care; prevention through hygiene and proper milking practices.

Myxomatosis.description: A highly contagious and often fatal viral disease of rabbits, causing skin tumors, swelling, and respiratory distress.
Myxomatosis.treatment: No specific antiviral treatment; supportive care may prolong life. Vaccination is key for prevention.

Pancreatitis.description: Inflammation of the pancreas, causing digestive enzyme leakage and potential systemic complications, common in dogs and cats.
Pancreatitis.treatment: Fluid therapy, pain management, anti-nausea medications, and dietary restrictions (e.g., low-fat diet).

Panleukopenia.description: Highly contagious and often fatal viral disease, primarily in cats (Feline Panleukopenia), causing severe gastrointestinal and immune suppression.
Panleukopenia.treatment: Intensive supportive care including IV fluids, anti-nausea meds, and antibiotics for secondary infections. Vaccination is highly effective.

Parvovirus.description: Highly contagious viral disease affecting dogs (Canine Parvovirus) or cats (Feline Panleukopenia), causing severe gastrointestinal symptoms.
Parvovirus.treatment: Aggressive supportive care (IV fluids, anti-nausea, antibiotics for secondary infections). Vaccination is crucial.

Pasteurellosis.description: Bacterial infection caused by Pasteurella species, causing respiratory disease ('shipping fever'), abscesses, or septicemia in various livestock.
Pasteurellosis.treatment: Antibiotics are effective. Vaccination is available for prevention in some species.

Pneumonia.description: Inflammation of the lungs, often caused by bacterial, viral, or fungal infections, leading to coughing, difficulty breathing, and fever.
Pneumonia.treatment: Antibiotics (if bacterial), antiviral/antifungal medications, anti-inflammatory drugs, and supportive care.

Porcine Circovirus Disease.description: A group of diseases in pigs caused by Porcine Circovirus Type 2 (PCV2), leading to wasting, respiratory signs, and reproductive failure.
Porcine Circovirus Disease.treatment: No specific antiviral; supportive care and vaccination are effective in control.

Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea.description: A highly contagious viral disease of pigs causing severe diarrhea, vomiting, and high mortality rates in piglets.
Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea.treatment: No specific antiviral; supportive care, hydration, and strict biosecurity measures. Vaccination helps reduce severity.

Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus.description: The specific coronavirus responsible for Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea (PED), causing severe enteric disease in pigs.
Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea Virus.treatment: Focuses on supportive care and preventing spread. Biosecurity and vaccination are critical for control.

Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syn.description: A viral disease (PRRSV) in pigs causing reproductive failure in breeding animals and respiratory disease in growing pigs.
Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syn.treatment: No specific antiviral; management involves supportive care, biosecurity, and vaccination to control outbreaks.

Porcine Respiratory Disease Complex.description: A multifactorial respiratory disease in pigs involving various pathogens (viruses and bacteria) and environmental factors.
Porcine Respiratory Disease Complex.treatment: Antibiotics (for bacterial components), anti-inflammatory drugs, and improved ventilation/management. Vaccination is common.

Rabbit Calicivirus.description: A highly contagious and often fatal viral disease in rabbits, causing internal hemorrhages and sudden death. Also known as Rabbit Hemorrhagic Disease.
Rabbit Calicivirus.treatment: No specific treatment; prevention is through vaccination and strict biosecurity.

Rabbit Hemorrhagic Disease.description: A highly contagious and lethal viral disease (RHDV) in rabbits, characterized by sudden death and internal bleeding.
Rabbit Hemorrhagic Disease.treatment: No effective treatment; vaccination is the primary means of prevention and control.

Rabbit Syphilis.description: Bacterial infection (Treponema cuniculi) in rabbits causing lesions around the face and genitals.
Rabbit Syphilis.treatment: Antibiotics (e.g., penicillin) are usually very effective.

Rabbit Viral Hemorrhagic Disease.description: Synonymous with Rabbit Hemorrhagic Disease, a deadly viral infection causing acute liver necrosis and hemorrhage in rabbits.
Rabbit Viral Hemorrhagic Disease.treatment: No cure; control relies on strict biosecurity and vaccination.

Respiratory Infection.description: General term for infections affecting the respiratory tract, caused by viruses, bacteria, or fungi, leading to coughing, sneezing, and difficulty breathing.
Respiratory Infection.treatment: Depends on the causative agent; may include antibiotics, antivirals, anti-inflammatory drugs, and supportive care.

Respiratory Syncytial Virus.description: A common respiratory virus in various species, causing mild to severe respiratory signs, especially in young animals.
Respiratory Syncytial Virus.treatment: Supportive care; no specific antiviral treatment commonly used in animals.

Ringworm.description: A common fungal infection of the skin, hair, and nails (dermatophytosis), causing circular patches of hair loss and scaling.
Ringworm.treatment: Topical antifungal creams, shampoos, or oral antifungal medications, depending on severity and spread.

Salmonellosis.description: Bacterial infection caused by Salmonella species, leading to diarrhea, fever, and sometimes septicemia in many animal species and humans.
Salmonellosis.treatment: Antibiotics (if severe or systemic), fluid therapy, and supportive care. Strict hygiene is essential to prevent spread.

Scrapie.description: A fatal, progressive neurodegenerative disease (prion disease) affecting sheep and goats, causing intense itching and neurological dysfunction.
Scrapie.treatment: No treatment; affected animals are culled to prevent spread. Genetic selection for resistance is a control method.

Scrapie Disease.description: Synonymous with Scrapie, a transmissible spongiform encephalopathy (prion disease) of sheep and goats, characterized by neurological signs.
Scrapie Disease.treatment: No treatment; eradication involves culling infected animals and genetic breeding programs for resistance.

Snuffles.description: A common term for bacterial upper respiratory infection in rabbits, often caused by Pasteurella multocida, leading to sneezing, nasal discharge, and sometimes pneumonia.
Snuffles.treatment: Antibiotics are used, but treatment can be prolonged and relapse is common due to chronic nature.

Strangles.description: Highly contagious bacterial infection (Streptococcus equi) of horses, causing fever, nasal discharge, and abscesses in lymph nodes, particularly in the throat.
Strangles.treatment: Isolation, hot packing of abscesses, and sometimes antibiotics. Vaccination is available for prevention.

Swine Dysentery.description: A contagious bacterial disease in pigs, causing severe diarrhea with mucus and blood, leading to dehydration and weight loss.
Swine Dysentery.treatment: Antibiotics (e.g., tiamulin, lincomycin) and strict biosecurity measures. Vaccination may be available in some regions.

Swine Erysipelas.description: Bacterial disease (Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae) in pigs causing diamond-shaped skin lesions, arthritis, and sudden death.
Swine Erysipelas.treatment: Antibiotics (e.g., penicillin) are effective. Vaccination is commonly used for prevention.

Swine Fever.description: A highly contagious viral disease of pigs, causing high fever, hemorrhages, and high mortality rates. Also known as Classical Swine Fever.
Swine Fever.treatment: No specific treatment; control involves culling, movement restrictions, and vaccination in endemic areas.

Swine Flu.description: A common term for influenza in pigs, caused by various influenza A viruses, leading to respiratory illness.
Swine Flu.treatment: Supportive care; antibiotics for secondary bacterial infections. Vaccination can reduce disease severity.

Swine Influenza.description: Viral respiratory disease in pigs caused by influenza A viruses, characterized by coughing, sneezing, and fever.
Swine Influenza.treatment: Supportive care; antibiotics for secondary bacterial infections. Vaccination is used for prevention and control.

Tick-Borne Disease.description: Diseases transmitted by ticks, caused by bacteria, viruses, or protozoa, leading to a variety of symptoms depending on the pathogen.
Tick-Borne Disease.treatment: Specific medications based on the pathogen (antibiotics, antiparasitics) and supportive care. Prevention relies on tick control.

Tuberculosis.description: A chronic bacterial disease (Mycobacterium species) affecting respiratory and other organ systems in various animals and humans.
Tuberculosis.treatment: Prolonged courses of multiple antibiotics; often involves culling in livestock due to public health concerns.

Upper Respiratory Infection.description: Infections affecting the nose, throat, and sinuses, commonly caused by viruses or bacteria, leading to sneezing, nasal discharge, and coughing.
Upper Respiratory Infection.treatment: Supportive care, fluids, and antibiotics if a bacterial component is present.

Viral Hemorrhagic Disease.description: A severe and often fatal viral disease in rabbits (Rabbit Hemorrhagic Disease) or other animals, causing internal bleeding.
Viral Hemorrhagic Disease.treatment: No specific antiviral treatment; prevention is through vaccination and strict biosecurity.

West Nile Virus.description: A mosquito-borne viral disease that can cause neurological symptoms in horses, birds, and humans.
West Nile Virus.treatment: Supportive care and anti-inflammatory drugs in affected animals. Vaccination is highly effective for prevention in horses.
